Well, this is partially true, except the strobing part. The electricity is crossing zero no matter what, all you're doing with the control is keeping it at zero longer. Most lights are smooth or smoothed so that there's not a difference if there's a dimmer or not. The ones without smoothing, like cheap versions of LED lights, will show strobing regardless if theres dimming or not.

Great video overall, very informative, but







'dimmer switches stay above the limit of the flicker fusion threshold, so we'd never see them' yea sure bud, try plugging in a simple LED into that dimmer switch and you'll see a SUPER annoying 120hz flashing, Good dimmable LEDs will use reletively complex circuitry to estimate the expected "dimness" based on how long the pulse should be, compared to how long it actually was, and then use PWM to flash those LEDs at 100s of times per second, so we dont see them, for reference, most people are capable of noticing strobing of bright lights at around 500hz, some younger people are capable of noticing strobing at and past 1000hz
Ironically, the most chill strobe lights have to strobe much faster than normal strobe lights so that instead of a flicker we just perceive them as dimmer constant light.

Fun fact, this is why older magnetically ballasted flourescent lights flicker. It's just at 120hz, which is well above the fusion threshold. (CFLs and electronically ballasted lights run FAR faster, often well into the kHz, such that the light actually remains at full brightness during the "zero crossing".)
It's usually not until the light is nearly burned out, and it's no longer really able to power up all the way, that this flicker really becomes noticable.
Office light ballasts are equipped with a "lead lag" function that offsets each bulb's flicker from the others, creating a far more even light from the fixture as a whole than a single bulb could achieve on a magnetic ballast.

Electronics jumped out the window at 0:40: larger resistor -> more wasted energy

That's simply wrong. The equation for heat dissipated by the resistor is P=V²/R=I²*R.

So if you change the resistor from 10Ω to 20Ω , then the power loss is half as big due to V²/R.

Larger resistors are being put into electronics to make them more energy efficient. If there was no resistor all current would flow unhindered -> congrats now your lightbulb is wasting all the energy it can.

There are so many errors in this, it is misleading. Incandescent light bulbs work by heating up the filament to a temperature where it emits light. When the light is dimmed, it is switched on and off, but this happens so quickly that it doesn't cool off, it just has a lower temperature, and therefore lower brightness, because the power being delivered to it is lower. LED lights dim by intelligent circuitry that limits their current. They do switch on and off rapidly, but this is smoothed out by capacitors and inductors, so there is no actual strobing.  Furthermore, if our lights were strobing at 120Hz, we would definitely noticed it. Some low quality LED bulbs lack a smoothing capacitor, and as a result they flicker at 120Hz (not 60Hz because it is full wave rectified). This is visible and very annoying. They also only talked about leading edge phase angle control dimmers, while many newer designs are trailing edge. SciShow, I usually love your content but this video is full of mistakes and misleading. It is poor quality, and I urge you to pull it immediately and issue a correction. Dimmers, while they do use a semiconductor to switch lights on and off, do not strobe, and even if they did, it would not be because of the dimming but because of the fact that the AC sine wave passes through zero 120 times a second.

ANYONE can EASILY see the 60Hz strobe in an unsmoothed LED bulb, you just need to not look at it. Your central vision is for detail but your peripheral vision is tuned to catch much quicker and subtle changes in brightness (presumably for detecting predators). You might notice this if you try to cover the light from a digital alarm clock, you can't see any light looking directly at it but it is glowing brightly in the corner of your eye. I'll advise anyone who gets the opportunity to see a CRT TV or Monitor to check it out from the corner of their eye and notice the flicker and then feel sorry for the British and Australians since theirs were even slower at only 50Hz.

To give some additional information: Not all dimmers work as described here.
There are basically 3 different types of dimming techniques: leading and trailing edge dimmers and PWM dimmers (technically leading and trailing edge dimmers count as PWM-dimmers too, but they are normally not called that).
Leading edge does not turn the power on until a variable time, so it cuts the front part of the sine wave.
Trailing edge cuts power off after a variable time, so it cuts the back part of a sine wave.
PWM dimmers produce a square wave, where they affect the t(on) and t(off) of the signal in a fixed time t. They can be used to dim LEDs.

One other note about these type of "sawed off" (pulse width modulated) sine waves - rather than the gradual ramp up to full voltage that you get with normal alternating current, these truncated waves rise very quickly and become practically square waves.  This introduces higher-frequency harmonics which is why you sometimes hear a high pitched squeal from a partially dimmed bulb...

Correction: what determines minimum frame rate for movies isn't flicker fusion but persistence of vision, a distinct phenomenon. However, motion picture projectors use rotating shutters that interrupt the light 2 or 3 times per frame to avoid obvious flickering, and that is because of flicker fusion. In the early silent era before the multiple bladed shutter was introduced the light was blocked only during "pulldown" of the next film frame and flickering was so noticeable movies were called "flickers" or "flicks," and the latter term obviously still persists.
